“I am the Cow-maker Myron’s Cow,
not a wrought Statue, therefore join in
poking my flanks and leading me to the plow.”
“Why, Myron, do you leave me here?
When will you free me to drive me to the stable?”

44. “The Calf shall low and the Bull love me
when he sees me; and the young cowherd
shall drive me to graze in the green meadows.”
“Even if Myron fashioned me from bronze
and put me here, I would bellow and roar
like a Bull, if only he had given me a tongue.”
“A Wasp, seeing this Cow, was deceived:
‘I have’ (she said) ‘never stung a harder Cow’s hide.’”

45. “Here Myron holds me, and Herders
push and strike me, for they believe that I
wish to stay behind for love of a bull.”
“Calf, why do you nuzzle at my teats?
Art has granted my udders no milk.”
“Myron, why do you imprison me on this stone?
You could have put me under the yoke and thus
I would have pulled the plow through your field.”

46. “Unless they touch my back
with their hands, people may behold me
at will from afar and close by, and never
accuse me of being made from hard bronze.”
“If Myron does not release my feet at once
from this pedestal, I will not escape death;
but if he wishes to free me,
I will walk among the flowers, like other Cows.”

47. Who can feed your hungry desire,
O youth, to depict all Animals,
not only Lions, but horrifying
Monsters and Dragons? There is nothing better
to keep you from going astray than to show you
Nature, where you will come upon some model.
Notice how each lies, walks, steps, or moves,
but treat all according to their essence.
right-middleThat there is nothing better, than to paint all things from life, noticing all actions, and in particular, treating them suitably.

ab.b: On Cloth or Drapery. The Tenth Chapter.
1. We have before us now a special subject that shall contribute to the excellence of Painting: that is, Cloth: which goes well with nakedness

div.ab: right-middleCloth, an important part, which contributes to excellence.
